newsitem.title: PERU: Palm Sunday brings renewed hope of hostage talks.
newsitem.headline: Palm Sunday brings renewed hope of hostage talks.

text.p: Roman Catholic faithful on Palm Sunday tried to rally the spirits of 72 hostages held by Peruvian rebels amid hope that talks to end the 96-day crisis at the Japanese ambassador's home may soon resume.

Parishioners from a working-class Lima district wore Biblical costumes and held a procession, complete with palm fronds and a man dressed as Jesus riding a donkey around the mansion in a show of support for the captives.
"We ask for forgiveness for the captors and freedom for the hostages," said Mario Valencia, 36, who played Jesus.

He led about 60 people playing the roles of shepherds, the Three Kings, Mary, Joseph and other religious figures, down streets surrounding the diplomatic compound reciting passages from the New Testament.
Hostages have spent Christmas and New Year's as captives of about 20 Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement (MRTA) rebels and appear likely to spend Easter, next Sunday, that way too.

Archbishop Juan Luis Cipriani, a mediator in the tense standoff between security forces and the MRTA, entered the home, towing a suitcase behind him, and spent two hours inside apparently delivering mass.
A local human rights umbrella group said the mass hostage- taking marred Peru's human rights in 1996 despite a decline in the number of people killed in political violence last year.

The National Human Rights Coordinator, in its annual report obtained by Reuters on Sunday, condemned the takeover as "reprehensible" and in violation of "principles established under international humanitarian law."

"This reprehensible act, although isolated, reminds us that even though they are weak and without public support, subversive groups continue to operate in different parts of the country," the report said.
President Alberto Fujimori spent Sunday in the Amazon lowland town of Pucallpa a day after the government announced it was ready to renew talks with hostage-takers.
"We are ready and hoping that at any moment the talks can resume," said government negotiator Domingo Palermo, who was accompanying Fujimori on Saturday on a visit to Lima's shanty- towns.
Other signs emerged on Saturday of progress in efforts to resolve the siege peacefully as the three-man mediation panel met for two hours with the rebels.
Cipriani told reporters afterward the rebels gave renewed assurances they would not hurt their captives -- a VIP list of cabinet ministers, ambassadors and businessman.

"We have received again from the MRTA a commitment to care for and treat respectfully all the hostages," Cipriani told reporters late on Saturday, but added: "We want to see them free. We don't want just more conversations."
Local newspapers reported on Sunday that Cipriani also called on the world community to offer suggetions for ending the crisis, and one observer painted a gloomy picture.
"The situation is one of total apathy," political analyst Raul Gonzales said.
Still, there were signs mediators were steering talks away from the rebels' main demand of freedom for 450 jailed comrades -- a demand flatly rejected by Fujimori.
First, Cipriani met for more than two hours with Cuban Ambassador Pedro Diaz, whose country along with the Dominican Republic has offered asylum to the hostage-takers.
Cipriani said he was only bidding goodbye to the ambassador before he returned to Havana, but the meeting prompted speculation they were working out asylum details.
The rebels blasted into a gala reception at the house on Dec. 17, and took hundreds of guests hostage, then released most in the days following the takeover.
Fujimori flew on Saturday with the Japanese envoy's wife to Pucallpa to distribute Japanese-donated blankets and clothes to flood victims, her first public activity since being released.
